The most likely cause of the issue described, where a technician receives an invalid certificate error on one workstation but not on others in the same local network, is:

A. Date and time

If the date and time settings on the workstation experiencing the issue are incorrect, it can lead to certificate validation errors. Certificates often have an expiration date, and if the system's date and time are not accurate, it may interpret the certificate as invalid. Ensure that the date and time settings on the affected workstation are correct and match those on the other workstations.

While C would be a more secure method for ensuring data is not retained, B is substantially faster and the question is asking for speed. If the question asked which is the best method for ensuring the data is wiped it would be C, but that is not the question.

Purpose of Standard Formatting
Standard/High-level formatting is setting up an empty file system on a disk partition or a logical volume and, for PCs, installing a boot sector. Often a fast operation and is sometimes referred to as quick formatting.

Purpose of Low-level wiping of a disk drive
Low-level wiping, also known as zero filling, involves writing zeros across an entire hard disk drive. It's a permanent deletion process that can be used for various reasons, including: 
Removing viruses: Destroying the boot sector can eliminate viruses that can't be removed otherwise. 
Switching operating systems: Completely removing everything from the drive when switching between OSes. 
Erasing confidential data: Permanently deleting sensitive information for privacy purposes. 
Scanning for bad sectors: Identifying and replacing bad sectors with good ones while writing to the sectors. 
Low-level wiping can also help identify bad sectors and allow the hard drive to reallocate them. However, it makes any previous data unrecoverable

Low-level formatting, also known as low-level wiping, is a process that prepares a hard drive by erasing all data and rebuilding its sectors and tracks. The goal is to ensure the drive is clean and free of any defects or leftover data.

Only allowing five password attempts disallows an attacker from brute forcing their way into a network/computer system, unless they had a good dictionary attack. Multifactor is always recommended for extra security, whether that extra step is a biometric access (Sometimes considered intrusive), or by a physical control access key, i.e. card badge reader. questions.question_text: The Chief Executive Officer at a bank recently saw a news report about a high-profile cybercrime where a remote-access tool that the bank uses for support was also used in this crime. The report stated that attackers were able to brute force passwords to access systems. Which of the following would BEST limit the bank's risk? (Choose two.)

choices.A: Enable multifactor authentication for each support account.
choices.C: Block all support accounts from logging in from foreign countries.
choices.B: Limit remote access to destinations inside the corporate network.
choices.D: Configure a replacement remote-access tool for support cases.
choices.F: Enforce account lockouts after five bad password attempts.
choices.E: Purchase a password manager for remote-access tool users.
